stops_and_affricate.description: Stops are consonants in which the vocal tract is blocked so that all airflow ceases. An affricate is a consonant that begins as a stop and releases as a fricative.

nasals.description: Nasals are consonants produced with a lowered velum in the mouth, allowing air to escape freely through the nose.

tap.description: A tap is a type of consonantal sound, made by a single muscle contraction.

fricatives.description: Fricatives are consonants produced by forcing air through a narrow channel made by placing two articulators close together.

approximants.description: Approximants are speech sounds that involve the articulators approaching each other but not narrowly enough nor with enough articulatory precision to create turbulent airflow.

front_vowels.description: Front vowels are articulated with the highest point of the tongue positioned towards the front of the mouth.

back_vowels.description: Back vowels are articulated with the highest point of the tongue positioned towards the back of the mouth.

low_central_vowel.description: A low central vowel is articulated with the tongue positioned as low and as central as possible in the mouth without creating a constriction that would be classified as a consonant.

diphthongs.description: Diphthongs are complex vowels composed of two adjacent vowel sounds within the same syllable.

triphthongs.description: Triphthongs are complex vowels composed of three adjacent vowel sounds within the same syllable.

vowel_length.description: Vowel length refers to the duration of the vowel sound.

syllable_structure.description: The syllable structure of a language determines how sounds can be combined to form syllables in that language.

tone.description: Tone involves the use of pitch to distinguish meaning of words in a language.
examples: High tone, Low tone, Falling tone, Rising tone

dahls_law.description: Dahlâ€™s Law describes a phonological process where a velar stop becomes a fricative when followed by another velar stop.

combining_vowels_across_morpheme_boundar.description: This rule describes how vowels from different morphemes combine when they are adjacent to each other.

syllable_initial_approximant_formation.description: This rule describes the formation of an approximant at the beginning of a syllable.

avoiding_sequences_of_three_vowels.description: This rule describes the avoidance of having three vowels in sequence within a word.

blocking_lengthening.description: This rule describes the prevention of vowel lengthening in certain phonological environments.
